title: Freemium Conversion Ceiling
context: SaaS companies adopt freemium models to reduce acquisition friction. Give the product away, let users experience value, then convert them to paid. The model works brilliantly for a few (Slack, Dropbox, Zoom) and fails quietly for most. The median freemium conversion rate is 2-5%. The free tier attracts users who never intended to pay, consumes support and infrastructure resources, and creates a ceiling that most companies cannot break through.
hypothesis: Freemium models drive growth by converting free users into paying customers at scale.

effects.label: Free tier attracts high volume of non-paying users

children.label: Infrastructure costs scale with users, not revenue
Support burden from free users diverts resources from paying customers
Free users set expectations that the product should remain free

effects.label: Product decisions optimize for free user retention, not paid conversion
effects.impact: Feature prioritization skews toward free tier

children.label: Free tier becomes too good — no reason to upgrade
Paywalling features feels punitive to established free users
Product team can't distinguish between 'engaged free' and 'will-pay' users

effects.label: Unit economics deteriorate
effects.impact: CAC/LTV ratio worsens as free users grow

children.label: Investors see user growth but revenue doesn't follow
Company raises prices on paid tier to compensate — alienating paying customers
Growth requires ever-larger top-of-funnel to maintain revenue growth
Company pivots to enterprise sales — freemium becomes a lead gen tool, not a business model

dontIf: Your product's value is immediately obvious and doesn't need a trial period
Your marginal cost per user is high (video, storage, compute-heavy products)
ifYouMust: Design the free tier as a time-limited or usage-limited trial, not an indefinite product
Instrument conversion triggers — know exactly what actions predict paid conversion
Set a hard ceiling on free tier infrastructure spend as a percentage of revenue
Build the paywall around the 'aha moment' — the feature that makes users say 'I need this'

alternatives.name: Free trial (time-limited)
alternatives.note: 14-30 day full access creates urgency and qualifies intent

alternatives.name: Reverse trial
alternatives.note: Start on paid features, downgrade to free after trial — users feel the loss

alternatives.name: Usage-based pricing
alternatives.note: Pay for what you use — aligns cost with value, no freeloaders

sources.title: OpenView Partners: Product Benchmarks 2024
sources.note: Median freemium conversion rate is 2-5%, top quartile reaches 7-10%

sources.title: ProfitWell: Freemium vs Free Trial Analysis
sources.note: Free trials convert at 2-3x the rate of freemium models

sources.title: a16z: The Freemium Business Model
sources.note: Analysis of when freemium works (low marginal cost, network effects) and when it doesn't

sources.title: Lenny Rachitsky: Freemium Conversion Benchmarks
sources.note: Comprehensive benchmark data across SaaS categories

falsifiability: The median SaaS freemium conversion rate exceeds 10% across a representative sample of 100+ companies
Free users generate positive unit economics through referrals, data, or indirect revenue that exceeds their cost to serve
Companies with freemium models reach profitability faster than comparable companies with paid-only models

seo.description: Freemium models project 10-15% conversion but deliver 2-5%. 95% of users never pay while consuming infrastructure and support. Unit economics quietly deteriorate.
